Having worked at BK, I don't really understand the allure of Charlie Scharf. Go back and look at his tenure there - same message. Going to cut costs and transform the bank. He must have supercharged that stock right? Nope. $44 to $41 on the stock. XLF performance during the same time frame? $22 to $27.
$60 by June-2022. The buy back program and earnings alone takes us there. Live long and prosper.

Look for Charlie to again buy back stock aggressively in Q4-21, perhaps even more so than in Q3, which would be quite an accomplishment. While the cap continues to restrict asset growth, by default it strongly supports a strong buy-back program over the next three to four quarters. Quarter over quarter EPS comparisions will be eye catching. Expect to see $60 by January 2022 end.

Looks like the dividend will remain at .2 cents per share. This shouldnt be a surprise to anyone and it is good news. Right now the money is being used for buybacks and raising the dividend would hurt that in a few different ways. I bet once the buybacks are complete the stock will be higher and they will be looking to increase it then. My estimate is Q3 of 2022...Either way it looks like the company is on a good path forward.

How the cap is going to help WFC weather this recession:They are no longer dependent on making money to boost stock price. There won’t be a slowdown in revenue that will hit all other financials. They have been forced to grow profits by cutting staff, not chasing new clients.
Wow WFC beat estimated earnings last 2 quarters, it is up 62% YTD, up 118% for the year. Yet there are still dopes bad mouthing the stock. My only regret is that I didn't buy a lot more of this bank.
